contentfulPage.title: Shared parental leave
contentfulPage.metaDescription: Details of how both parents or partners can share time off after having a child or adopting.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Shared parental leave gives you and your partner the chance to divide between you any remaining leave after the first two weeks after the birth or adoption.

You need to have worked for a certain amount of time to qualify, but shared parental leave gives you and your partner more flexibility to care for and bond with your child.
The information on this page applies to staff employed on AVDC, BCC, C&SB, WDC, and Buckinghamshire Council Terms and Conditions.

You need to take at least two weeks’ maternity leave after your child is born, or two weeks’ adoption leave, but after this you can share between you the up to 50 weeks’ leave remaining.

Shared parental leave has to be taken within the first year after the birth or placement of your child.

You must be the:

  • Mother or adopting parent
  • Birth father or spouse, civil partner or partner of the child’s mother / adopting parent

You must have worked for the council for 26 weeks by the end of the 15th week before your baby is due or the expected date you’ll be matched with a child for adoption.

Your partner must have been employed for 26 weeks out of the 66 weeks (not necessarily continuously) before the week your baby is due to be born, or the week you’re told that you’ve been matched with a child for adoption.

They must have earned at least £30 a week on average during any 13 of those weeks, but again not necessarily continuously.

If your partner hasn’t been working or is self-employed, they won’t be entitled to take shared parental leave.

If both parents want to take shared parental leave, then you can take your leave at the same time or at different times.

Shared parental leave must be:

  • For at least one week
  • Taken in multiples of whole weeks
  • Taken as one period or up to three separate periods of time

This means you or your partner can go back to work after maternity / adoption leave is over but still take shared parental leave at a later date.

The father or partner can take shared parental leave at any time. You can also take it when the other partner is on paternity leave or unpaid parental leave.

collapsibleLinks.title: Giving notice to end maternity / adoption leave

childMarkdownRemark.html:
If you want to end maternity / adoption leave early so you can take advantage of shared parental leave, you need to tell your manager at least eight weeks earlier.

You can give notice to end maternity / adoption leave before or after the birth or matching date, but if it’s after then it is binding and you won’t be able to restart your maternity leave and pay. If you give notice before the birth or matching date, you can always change back up to six weeks after the birth / matching date.

Please fill out the Maternity / Adoption Leave Curtailment Notice and give it to your manager and HR.

collapsibleLinks.title: Giving notice to take shared parental leave

childMarkdownRemark.html:
You must fill out the Notice of Entitlement and Intention form and give this to your manager eight weeks before you want shared parental leave to start.

You can vary the amount of shared parental leave you want to take by writing to your manager. Please use the Variation of Notice of Entitlement and Intention form

There is no limit on the number of times you can make changes to shared parental leave, so long as this is done before the formal Period of Leave Notice has been given.

Only three Period of Leave notices can be given by each parent. This includes requests to vary a period of leave that has already been arranged.

If you ask for one continuous period of leave, then you'll be able to take this, but your manager can say no to requests for periods of discontinuous leave.

Once they have agreed the times with you, they will sign any forms and send them to HR. You should get a letter back confirming everything in writing.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
You can take 20 paid days’ work during your leave period without losing your entitlement to Shared Parental Leave or pay. These are called Shared Parental Leave in Touch or SPLIT days.

SPLIT days help you to keep in touch with any developments at work. You don’t have to work SPLIT days and your manager can’t make you work these days.

You can claim for SPLIT days by completing a SPLIT days claim form. You’ll be paid for the number of hours you work, but the total amount you receive can’t be more than your normal full pay.

Whether you work one hour or a full day, this will count as one of your 20 SPLIT days. If your manager agrees, you could use SPLIT days to work part of a week during your shared parental leave.
